--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbr@d...> wrote:
> So said  Mike Colbert <mbcolbert@y...>  on  12/15/2002
> --------------------

> >To me, it smacks of self-righteousness and shameless 
> >self-promotion.

Comes in handy as a consultant.

> I wrote "JUnit: A Starter Guide" [...]
> Let me ask you, am I wrong to be proud of that and to refer people 
> to it if they ask for a tutorial?

Na.. it's a good piece of work.  I've recomended it to people.
 
> See, this is just sad. First, I'm not "his buddy".

Now you've hurt my feelings :(

> Dave and I have exchanged the odd e-mail, but we hardly know each 
> other.

Hoping to remedy that at soem point.

> I trust that Dave
> will tackle your problem in an upcoming Coad letter.

Planning to.  Probably the Feb. issue.

> I thought it was
> rude of you to insist he get off his ass and answer your question right
> now.

Ya.. it's not like I'm starting a new contract, moving to D.C.,
finding an apartment, learning my way around, living in a hotel,
writing newsletters, finishing a book, or anything of that sort ;-)

> Be aware that we could be charging hundreds of dollars per
> day for our advice.

And I, for one, do.

> We are volunteers here.

Yes, and it's very mutual.  I've learned a lot on these lists, and try
every now & then to give something back.  Being blasted when I do
doesn't make it any easier.  It's a good thing I have a sense of humor
(granted it's obtuse at times, and generally off-color).

> I hope that my other reply
> made it clearer what I think Dave was getting at: most people
> misunderstand (as I did for two years) why the class TestCase is 
> meant to embody a test fixture. 

Exactly

Dave
